trial_identification.studytitle: The objective of this study is to see the effects of changing dairy intake in healthy New Zealand participants on blood levels of ruminant trans fats, and on the metabolic syndrome
trial_identification.scientifictitle: single centre randomised controlled study to assess the effects of changing dairy intake for 1 month on components of the metabolic syndrome and on fatty acids in healthy volunteers

interventions.interventions: Arm 1- increased dairy consumption by 2 standards servings/day Arm 2- eliminate all dairy as much as possible Arm 3- no change for 4 weeks. All participants had a one to one session with a study co ordinator with exerience in giving dietary advice on on one. A sheet with tips on how to change dairy intake(when applicable) was also given to all participants

primaryOutcome.outcome: To determine whether dietary advice to increase or decrease dairy intake significantly changes plasma levels of vaccenic acid and palmitelaidic acid in participants.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To determine whether dietary changes in TFA are associated with changes in serum CRP levels
To determine whether dietary changes in TFA are associated with changes in BP levels at the 1 month clinic visit
To determine whether dietary changes in TFA are associated with changes in plasma lipids levels
To determine whether dietary changes in TFA are associated with changes in insulin resistance levels as calculated using the HOMA model of fasting serum insulin and plasma glucose levels

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Aged over 18 years of age Able to give informed consent
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Unwilling to trial dietary intervention 2. lactose intolerant/milk allergy 3. pregnant/lactating 4. Known vitamin D deficiency or hypocalcaemia 5. Osteoporosis. 6. Inflammatory conditions e.g. rheumatoid arthritis 7. On a statin 8. Known cardiovascular disease (stroke, ischemic heart disease, peripheral vascular disease)

trial_design.concealment: Allocation was concealed by sealed opaque envelopes
trial_design.sequence: computer generated random allocation- blocks of 60

ethicsAndSummary.summary: It is well established that industrial trans fatty acids (TFA) are harmful to health however, little is known about the effects of the natural TFA found in dairy. Some like the FDA feel that all TFA is harmful and have recommended that intake be limited as much as possible. An observational study by CVRU suggests that dairy TFAs may be harmful to cardiac health. Conversely a recent Harvard University observational cross sectional study observed that these isomers reduced insulin resistance. This interventional study is a randomised clinical study in 180 participants and assesses the effects of changing dairy intake on TFA, inflammatory markers, lipids, insulin resistance and anthropomorphic parameters.
